NewsLines.HeadLine: U.S. stocks sink, Nasdaq flounders at six-year low

NewsLine.NewsLineText: MARKETS-USA-STOCKS (UPDATE 5):U.S. stocks sink, Nasdaq flounders at six-year low

body.p: NEW YORK, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Stocks sank in late morning trade on Monday, tossing the Nasdaq to its lowest level since 1996, as dim outlooks from companies ranging from telecom gear maker JDS Uniphase Corp. to retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. fanned worries over corporate health.

"We had come to a point where earnings revisions had come down in terms of magnitude with every quarter, but now they seem to be accelerating," said Owen Fitzpatrick, head of U.S. equity group at Deutsche Bank Private Banking, which oversees $7 billion.

An early stream of profit warnings is bucking a trend that began in the fourth quarter of 2001, when more companies offered positive outlooks and fewer offered negative ones, according to Thomson First Call. The ratio between those two kept improving into the second quarter of 2002, but the trend is starting to reverse.

The threat of a second Gulf War added to Wall Street's cloud of worries and triggered a spike in oil prices. Iraq vowed to reject any new Security Council resolution differing from an agreement reached with the U.N. secretary-general, while President George W. Bush reviewed military options for a possible attack on the oil-rich nation.

The tech-laced Nasdaq Composite Index lost 31 points, or 2.60 percent, to 1,189, on track to close below 1,200 for the first time since since September 1996. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average sank 157 points, or 1.97 percent, to 7,829, after dropping more than 2 percent earlier. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 15 points, or 1.85 percent, to 829.

JDS, the world's top supplier of components and modules that boost the speed and capacity of optical networks, added its voice to the chorus of companies hurt by sharp slowdown in the telecommunications market. JDS fell 8 cents to $2.06 after trimming its first-quarter sales guidance.

Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, added more pressure to the market with a $2.33 drop to $52.37. The Dow member said it expects September sales at stores open at least a year to come in near the low end of its growth forecast. Home improvement retailer Home Depot Inc. fell $1.65 to $29.58, adding more pressure to the Dow.

Tyco International Ltd. fell 81 cents to $14.15 and ranked as the most active on the New York Stock Exchange. Though Tyco's board has said it was unaware of extravagant pay and loans given to top executives, minutes of the board's compensation committee show it knew of many of the payments months before the board took steps to disclose them, The New York Times reported.

Microsoft Corp. fell $2.28 to $45.18 and weighed on the Dow. Soundview Technology Group said the software giant is expensive and it will be difficult for Microsoft to show significant additional growth without a return in personal computer growth and information technology spending.

Dole Food Co., the world's largest producer of fresh fruits, emerged as a bright spot in the market with a $5.26 jump to $29.75. The company's chief executive offered to take Dole private with a $1.26 billion cash bid.

Nucor Corp., the largest U.S. steel recycler, tumbled $8.43, or more than 17 percent, to $40.55. The company said third-quarter earnings would fall below previous estimates due to weakened demand for non-residential construction activity and higher mill start-up costs.

Semiconductor stocks dragged on the market after Credit Suisse First Boston cut its investment outlook on 14 chip equipment makers, including Applied Materials Inc. and KLA-Tencor Corp., citing a dampened capital spending environment. Applied Materials fell 31 cents to $11.62, while KLA-Tencor dropped 66 cents to $27.36.
